tit.e: Ancient Chinese Chromatic Scale (primarily used in Japan for gagaku, etc.)
Ancient Chinese Chromatic Scale (primarily used in Japan for gagaku, etc.)
Ancient Chinese Chromatic Scale (primarily used in Japan for gagaku, etc.)

sen.j: 十二律（じゅうにりつ）とは、中国や日本の伝統音楽で用いられる12種類の標準的な高さの音。
sen.e: Ancient Chinese chromatic scale is the twelve kinds of average pitch that are used in Chinese or Japanese traditional music.
Ancient Chinese chromatic scale is the twelve kinds of average pitch that are used in Chinese or Japanese traditional music.
Ancient Chinese chromatic scale is the twelve kinds of average pitch that are used in Chinese or Japanese traditional music.

sen.j: 三分損益法によって1オクターブ間に平均律でない半音の間隔で配された12の音である。
sen.e: These are the twelve tones arranged at intervals of semitone, which is not a temperament, within an octave, using the principle of the sanfen sunyi.
These are the twelve tones arranged at intervals of semitone, which is not a temperament, within an octave, using the principle of the sanfen sunyi.
These are the twelve tones arranged at intervals of semitone, which is not a temperament, within an octave, using the principle of the sanfen sunyi.

sen.j: 律とは本来、音を定める竹の管であり、その長さの違いによって12の音の高さを定めた。
sen.e: Ritsu (melody) originally refers to a bamboo tube that determines the tone, and the twelve kinds of music pitch were set based on the difference between the bamboo tubes.
Ritsu (melody) originally refers to a bamboo tube that determines the tone, and the twelve kinds of music pitch were set based on the difference between the bamboo tubes.
Ritsu (melody) originally refers to a bamboo tube that determines the tone, and the twelve kinds of music pitch were set based on the difference between the bamboo tubes.

sen.j: 周代において確立した。
sen.e: It was established in the Zhou period.
It was established in the Zhou period.
It was established in the Zhou period.

sen.j: 中国の律を低いものから高いものへと並べ、西洋音楽の音名と対照すると以下のようになる（規準音である黄鐘をCとした場合。）
sen.e: The following is the Ritsu of China that are placed in the order of lowest to highest, in comparison with the pitch name of western music (Kosho (the first note of the ancient chromatic scale); the reference tone, is set at C.)
sen.cmt: B10をB9に結合し、再度分割しました。一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: The following is the Ritsu of China that are placed in the order of lowest to highest, in comparison with the pitch name of western music (Kosho [the first note of the ancient chromatic scale]; the reference tone, is set at C).
sen.cmt: ピリオドの位置を移動、カッコ表記修正
sen.e: The following is the Ritsu of China that are placed in the order of lowest to highest, in comparison with the pitch name of western music (Kosho [the first note of the ancient chromatic scale]; the reference tone, is set at C).

sen.j: なお十二律は陰陽に分けられる。
sen.e: Ancient Chinese Chromatic Scale divided into yin and yang (positive and negative, or light and shade).
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Ancient Chinese Chromatic Scale is divided into yin and yang (positive and negative, or light and shade).
Ancient Chinese Chromatic Scale is divided into yin and yang (positive and negative, or light and shade).

sen.j: 奇数の各律は陽律であり、律と呼ばれ、六律（りくりつ）と総称される。
sen.e: The odd numbered Ritsu is the Yan tune, and individually called the Ritsu, and are collectively called the Rikuritsu.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: The odd numbered Ritsu is the Yan tune, and individually called the Ritsu, and are collectively called the Rikuritsu.
The odd numbered Ritsu is the Yan tune, and individually called the Ritsu, and are collectively called the Rikuritsu.

sen.j: 偶数の各律は陰律であり、呂と呼ばれ、六呂（りくりょ）と総称される。
sen.e: The even-numbered Ritsu is the Yin tune, and are collectively called the Rikuryo.
The even-numbered Ritsu is the Yin tune and individually called the Ryo, and are collectively called the Rikuryo.
sen.cmt: 「呂と呼ばれ」→訳漏れのため訳出しました。
sen.e: The even-numbered Ritsu is the Yin tune and individually called the Ryo, and are collectively called the Rikuryo.

sen.j: よって律呂の名がある。
sen.e: The name of Ritsu Ryo came from this.
The name of Ritsu Ryo came from this.
The name of Ritsu Ryo came from this.

sen.j: 日本では、Dを壱越（いちこつ）と呼び、以下断金（たんぎん）・平調（ひょうじょう）・勝絶（しょうぜつ）・下無（しもむ）・双調（そうじょう）・鳧鐘（ふしょう）・黄鐘（おうしき）・鸞鏡（らんけい）・盤渉（ばんしき）・神仙（しんせん）・上無（かみむ）と呼ぶ。
sen.e: In Japan, D is called the Ichikotsu (in Japan, the first note of the ancient chromatic scale (approx. D)), and the following is called the tangin (the second note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), hyojo (the third note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), shozetsu (the fourth note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), simomu (the fifth note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), Sojo (the sixth note of the ancient chromatic scale), fusho (the seventh note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), oshiki (the eighth note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), rankei (the ninth note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), banshiki (the tenth note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), shinsen (the eleventh note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), and kamimu (the twelfth note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale) in sequence.

In Japan, D is called the ichikotsu (in Japan, the first note of the ancient chromatic scale [approx. D]), and the following is called the tangin (the second note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), hyojo (the third note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), shozetsu (the fourth note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), simomu (the fifth note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), sojo (the sixth note of the ancient chromatic scale), fusho (the seventh note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), oshiki (the eighth note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), rankei (the ninth note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), banshiki (the tenth note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), shinsen (the eleventh note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), and kamimu (the twelfth note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale) in sequence.
sen.cmt: カッコ表記修正、他の音名に合わせ、Ichikotsu、Sojoの頭文字を小文字に変更
sen.e: In Japan, D is called the ichikotsu (in Japan, the first note of the ancient chromatic scale [approx. D]), and the following is called the tangin (the second note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), hyojo (the third note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), shozetsu (the fourth note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), simomu (the fifth note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), sojo (the sixth note of the ancient chromatic scale), fusho (the seventh note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), oshiki (the eighth note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), rankei (the ninth note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), banshiki (the tenth note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), shinsen (the eleventh note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale), and kamimu (the twelfth note of the ancient Japanese chromatic scale) in sequence.
